Wrote a book about making money online Amazon.com: Digital Hustle: How to Make Real Money Online eBook: G Rummy: Kindle Store More on that later. For now let’s cover making money with blogs. There are a lot of perks to blogging: sponsorship, invite to exclusive events, even to the point of gaining celebrity status, as we obviously see with most fashion bloggers today. Although it’s seen as a full proof way of earning primary income that some bloggers started to quit their jobs to focus on blogging, it’s also a steep climb to success. You can’t simply start a blog and assume you’ll gain readers and get paid. You can start free but may need to invest on a couple of things to upgrade your status. There’s a ton of organization involved. There are 5 main steps to becoming a blogger: Build your Blog Before you become a blogger, obviously you need to set up your website first. Here are a few things to consider: Domain and Hosting Domain is like your house in the online world. It has its own address called a URL, for example, http://www.yourdomain.com. Hosting is the lot where your house is built. It’s your own piece of virtual space, to say the least. You basically need both to exist in the online world. Now, getting a domain and a hosting plan could be pricey and some people do not want to invest as much before they can even start gaining traction online. Truth be told, domain, depending on demand and availability cost from $1.99 (on the first year) to a million dollars. Hosting plans, depending on the bandwidth you need, cost $3.99 to a few thousand dollars, both on a monthly plan. If you want to start free, you can opt to register on a blogging platform, like Blogger, Wordpress, and Tumblr. Signing up for these sites get you an account that works like a free bunk bed. Of course, the perks of having your own house and lot on the web will never compare to a free bunk bed. Signing up for free accounts will never work as great as having your own domain and hosting. Blogging Platform If you’re not a talented coder, nor have the time to learn setting up websites from the ground up, you can sign up for a blogging platform instead, as mentioned earlier. Blogger, Wordpress, Tumblr, and many more offer bloggers with the necessary tools to build their website. As soon as you set up your account, you will still get that .Blogger.com - Create a unique and beautiful blog. It’s easy and free. or .WordPress.com: Create a free website or blog tag with your free domain. If you don’t want that and feel that a .com or .org sounds more professional, you can also try linking your domain and hosting to your blogging platform. Theme and Layout Your website’s look and feel should be your primary concern when it comes to branding. Use a design that sits well with how you want your site to appeal to your audience. Make your own logo and blog banner. Post creative and engaging content As soon as your blog is set up, it’s time to start uploading engaging content. By engaging content, I mean 3 things: Make sure it’s relevant to your niche Make sure it’s relevant to your audience Make sure it’s generally interesting and informative All these are quite easy to spell out, but challenging to execute. There are bloggers who stick to their niche e.g. Beauty and Fashion, Technology, Travel, etc… And there are those who jump from one random niche to another. Try not to be the latter. If you want to keep your momentum and start earning as fast as possible, be consistent with your content. Market your blog as a brand Simply uploading your content will not make you an overnight blogging superstar. This is actually the tricky part--getting your blog out there. As stated earlier, money-making in blogging is a steep climb, and in this part, it just gets steeper. Here are a couple of things to note: SEO Search engine optimization is how your website can be searchable online. Would you like to simply be available online? Or would you prefer to be on the top spot in Google search results? From indexing your website to search engines like Google, Yahoo, AOL and much more, to learning how to monitor your statistics and the relevant factors that come into play, SEO is entirely a separate ebook to go through. It is a tough cookie to crack but once mastered, it will definitely boost your visibility online. Social media Social media is a great way to connect with people, and that’s technically what you want to achieve. Being active in social media, gaining followers and building a community increases your chances of getting sponsorships. Advertisers have a certain radar for bloggers who are huge influencers, you know. Email marketing Another way to stay connected with your readers is through email marketing. From sending blog updates to promoting brands, email marketing is a great thing to manage for your blog. The number of your subscribers are also the testament to your online presence and will be a great highlight to your media kit. Leverage your online presence This is the part where you start reaping the harvest of your hard work. We all know that being able to make money off what you’re passionate about is la dolce vita. It’s like the world is rewarding you for sharing your talent and heart to your community. The one thing you need to have in order to attract advertisers is a page that lists all the services you offer as well as your rates. This is in order to: a) let them know that you’re okay with promoting their brand; b) make them aware that your blog is only going to blog about businesses that relate to your particular niche, and c) to inform them of how much you value your blog. Now on to the ways to make money through blogging: Sponsored posts When a company discovers you online and sees how huge your network is, they may want to take the opportunity and ask you to promote their brand, in exchange for some cha-ching of course. They will send you an email detailing how they want to be promoted: the specific links and keywords you need to incorporate in the write up; the photos, posters or videos they want to include; as well as discount codes and coupons that can help them make sales through your blog. Sponsored posts is a one-time thing. If the company makes a ton of profit after you promoted their brand, they’ll come back for more. This leads to… Blog Sponsorship When you’re too valuable for the company as their marketing partner, they’d want to seal the deal with you and offer you a contract indicating that as their brand ambassador, you’ll be entitled to their exclusive perks (free stuff, event invite, etc...) under the premise that you should post every so often about them and that you are not allowed to promote other competing brands. This is a business relationship that you’d want to take care of in order to sustain a sizeable profit for your blog. Product Review Bloggers are famous for sharing their opinions about everything online and as much as companies try to partner up for marketing purposes, sometimes they want to hit 2 birds with one stone and include market research too. They send in free products for the bloggers to try out and post a review on their blog. It may either be a hit or miss for those companies, but nevertheless a great way to get their brand out there and pick up on how they can improve their products. Ads and Affiliate Links Advertisement in the form of banners in your blog can help you earn money by simply uploading your sponsor’s banner on your website. This banner will link back to their website. Some companies pay a flat rate for a specific amount of time and some also offer pay-per-click or pay-per-purchase schemes. Affiliate links are generated links that, depending on the platform you use, will earn you points or dollars every time a) a viewer clicks on their banner or link on your blog, b) a viewer clicks on the banner/link and makes a purchase on their website, and c) a viewer clicks on the banner/link and signs up for an account. This will be explained more in detail in Chapter 6. Selling your products Blogging can also be a gateway for reaching people online. If you’re selling physical items, blogging is also a great way to reach out to your audience and sell your products by sharing information related to your products. For example, if you’re selling properties, it would really help to blog about say, the different types of properties, things to check before buying a house or how a property increases or decreases value over time. Helping educate your readers through your blog will definitely increase their trust in the services or products you’re offering. Making money through e-commerce will be further discussed in Chapter 12. You don’t always have to sell physical products. Through your blog, you can also offer services like web design, virtual assistance, e-courses, and the list goes on.

Everyone always says this (because it's true), but the best way for a blogger to make money is to not treat the site like a business. It's just too tough to make a living blogging - you have to have a passion for what you're writing about and hope that it pays off. Advertising is ok! If you choose an ad network that spews flashing auto-audio ads in every direction, or use text-link ads that trick people into clicking on them, people will become annoyed. If you sell the standard ad sizes, or small, custom (well integrated) sponsorships, why would your viewers care?  Transparency is one of the best ways to get your readers on your side. Make them feel involved in the decision. A quick post that says "My server costs a lot of money, I'm thinking about advertising, will you hate me?" will almost always get a positive, supportive reaction. Make it clear that you'll do your best to keep the ads from being obnoxious, or offer an ad-free subscription solution. You don't have to be pushy, but if they want to buy it, it's there! - Merchandise. If you have a very tight community, consider creating branded merchandise or shirts with inside jokes spawned from inside the community.  - If you have a newsletter, consider getting sponsors to pay for their ad to be included. There are a million different ways to go with this and as long as you're honest with your community, they'll support you.

The guys that I know who blog are still at it daily and try to introduce valuable insights for their readers.  The blogger is their man on the streets or in that niche that provides valuable and actionable insights. That's the ultimate goal.  One of these bloggers also has a subscription newsletter that he publishes 5 times a week, Monday through Friday.  So he is constantly working at providing actionable, relevant information. His attentions are peeled constantly on all things related to the 5 or 6 topics that he covers.  He does enjoy argument, in part, because he's good at it.   INCOME SOURCE #1:  AD REVENUEOnce you've got a blog up and running, create an Adsense account.  That's first.  This places ads on your site and tracks the advertising activity on your site.  You need to have ads on your site if you want to earn a microstream of income.  That's what it's about--having multiple microstreams of income.  Set a goal of $2,000 as you did or $5,000 just so that you have something to measure your efforts by.  Then execute the tasks chasing the nickels and quarters and $1.15 activities.  Remember, you're doing this as you're learning the kinds of topics your audience seeks when they come to your site.  Also, if you're going to create a subscription newsletter, be sure that your audience for that newseltter are people who have money. You do not want to sell RVs to people in the ghetto just struggling to survive.  INCOME SOURCE #2: TRAFFIC LEADS TO VIEWS & CLICKSSocial Media.  If you're using a WordPress website every post you write can be sent out automatically to several social media sites at once.  Twitter is a great place for this.  The reason why Twitter is a great place is because you can create an audience there simply by following key, top, or well-known folks in your niche.  If your niche is cooking, then follow as many chefs, foodie authors, TV personalities related to cooking or food as you can. When you write a post and distribute it through Twitter a small percentage of those you follow in Twitter will at least view your post if for no other reason than they are curious.  Jon Davis stated that "you can't suck at writing and [you have to] have something of value people want to read."  This is absolutely true.  So you can see that a lot of skills are required.  And I doubt that you can outsource these initially.  If you do, it's going to cost you.  You can try Freelancer or Fivver to produce some articles for you.  But the search engines really prefer fresh and original material.  So does your audience. The more you write they better you will get at writing headlines.  In the world of 144 characters and social media, people act first on headlines.  If it's catchy, if it's interesting, if it's in the wheelhouse of contemporary news people will bite. The more you write and the more you post, the better you'll have an understand of how to write headlines that get looks.   If your site is a health food blog, you might want to recommend a particular vitamin or brand of vitamin.  When you do that be sure to get an embed link from Amazon for the product.  Or do the same thing with books or any merchandise found at Amazon, say, watches or electronics, whatever your niche is.  The embed link will show up as a product icon.  When someone reads your post, say, on the benefits of Magnesium and you have a link to Solgar's Magnesium in your post you are providing yourself with an opportunity to earn a few nickels there.  Remember, it's all about microstreams.  Multiple microstreams of income.  This is one of the reasons why it's hard to give an answer to your question of how to make $2,000 a month is because so much goes into making a little bit of money. But if you're relentless, if you're tenacious, and if you're maniacally focused, not only will you learn a lot but you'll also begin to earn something. WRITE A POST IN ANSWER TO A QUESTION/THREAD @ OTHER SITESVisit other sites and comment on comments and/or articles at that site. Instead of writing a quick snarky comment to downdress someone you disagree with, write a post addressing the problem and offer solutions with an informed opinion and then paste a link to your post in their comments sections.  If that thread has 15 comments, then you'll attract a percentage of those 15 commenters. What you do is answer or address the article in a post and then paste your post in those comments.  Think of how many people following that thread will open that link to your post. These are 8 ways to make money with a blog. 1. PPC Advertising (Adsense) The easiest and fastest way to monetize a blog is through PPC advertising. What sets AdSense apart from other advertising systems is that you don't choose the ads that are shown... Google does it for you. 2. Advertising CPA - Cost-per-Action In this case, when a reader clicks on your ad, it is redirected to a landing page where you have to take an action, such as opening an account, filling out a survey or giving your personal information to receive more information. For each user who completes the action, you take a commission. 3. Private advertisers Just as magazines rent their pages to companies, you can rent areas of your blog to companies in the sector for a fixed monthly price. 4. Affiliate marketing Affiliate marketing is nothing more than a specific type of CPA (Cost-per-Action) advertising in which the action is that the user has to buy something. So, you act as a commercial, promoting on your blog a product or service from another company, which pays you a commission each time you generate a sale. 5. Own products The most lucrative method to make money with your blog is to sell your own products since there are no intermediaries and consequently, the margins are wider. 6. Services Having a blog and writing frequently on a topic will help you position yourself as an expert in your niche. After a while, you can take advantage of that authority to offer your services. As over the months, you have shown that you know about your field and have established a relationship of trust with your readers, some of them may be interested in what you offer and become customers. The key to this model is the trust. 7. Promotion of your business If you already have a business, a blog can be a fantastic marketing tool. Your clients are interested in knowing who you are, how you work, and how things work on backstage. 8. You want to make money, right? Of course you do. Everyone wants – and needs -to make money. So you started a blog since you’ve heard it’s an easy way to make cash, but you’re not quite sure how to actually make money doing it. Or maybe you already have a blog and you’re exploring ways to monetize it.  No matter which group you’re in, making money with a blog – whether it’s a hobby blog or a business blog –is possible. It’s not a get rich quick ordeal, but if you do it right, you could make enough to support your family and more. Let’s dive in and see how you can make a profit with your blog.  One of the most common ways bloggers make money is through placing ads on their site. There are two popular types of ads: CPC/PPC Ads: Cost per click (also called pay per click) ads are usually banners that you place in your content or sidebar. Each time a reader clicks on the ad, you are paid for that click.CPM Ads: CPM Ads, or “cost per 1,000 impressions,” are ads that pay you a fixed amount of money based on how many people view your ad.Include Affiliate Links in Your ContentAffiliate marketing is also another great tool for monetizing your blog. Sell Digital ProductsIf you would rather not advertise other people’s products on your site, or if you are looking for another stream of income, consider selling digital products. This can include items like: eBooksOnline courses/workshopsImages, video, or music people can use in their own contentApps, plugins, or themesUse it as a Content Marketing Tool for Your Business It is also possible to sell physical products on your blog and to make money that way. Instead of thinking of it as making money from your blog, however, think of your blog as a content marketing tool that will drive visitors to your business website.

It is – with a good blog, you can definitely make a living with blogging and if you want to take things to the next step, you could make hundreds of thousands a year. Get yourself an editorial calendar, plan your content in advance, set goals and strategize the content you create so that it helps you achieve those goals and then keep to your schedule. Then, you also need to work on promoting your content. Build a following on social media, interact on other, similar blogs, guest blog on other websites, join blogging communities and so on. Don’t launch until your blog is correctly set up No matter how tempting it may be, you don’t want to launch your blog too early. Make sure you have covered the basics, such as having  an about and contact pages, as well as a decent looking design. Your design doesn’t have to be unique—you can just use a free WordPress theme. As well, make sure you are using Feedburner to track your RSS feed and Google Analaytics to track your visitors. Pick a topic and stick with it Even though it’s your blog and you can write on whatever you want, you have to pick a topic and stick with it. Your blog will be much more popular if you stick with one topic. Be consistent If you have a lot to say and a ton of time, blog daily. If you don’t have much time on your hands or much to say, blog once a week. Once you figure out how often you are going to blog, stick with it. The quickest way to lose your audience is inconsistency. If you aren’t sure how often you can blog, start off by blogging once a month. If you happen to have more time, you can step it up and blog more often. Just don’t reduce the number of times you are blogging. Now that your blog is a few days old, you should start seeing some comments. Although  standard practice only dictates that you read every comment on your blog, you should also make an effort to respond to each and every commentator. If you don’t, some of your commentators may feel like you are ignoring them. Responding to every commentator will help you build a loyal following, which will help build up your traffic in the long run. Stop regurgitating content Don’t just blog about the news or about something you saw on another blog. If you are going to write about the same topics as everyone else, make sure you throw in your two cents. People are reading your blog because they want to hear from you…right? It’s best to give them what they want by providing your opinion. Ideally, you should only be blogging when you have something new and exciting to say. Don’t be afraid to take risks Most bloggers are afraid of saying what they really think, especially when it is something negative. Don’t be afraid to take risks, even if most other bloggers don’t take them. If you really feel a specific way about something, then write about it, no matter how negative or positive it may be . Controversy is one of the quickest ways to build a large following because it will cause other bloggers to link to you. Just don’t abuse this  power by writing controversial posts for no reason. If you do, it could end up backfiring. Differentiate yourself Like anything else, you will have competitors. So if you want people to read your blog instead of your competition’s, you’ll have to do something unique. It doesn’t have to be anything crazy, just something different. For example, if you blog about entrepreneurship — so do  thousands of other bloggers. The wayyou would try to differentiate yourself is by writing detailed content that helps entrepreneurs take action. Entrepreneurs can get information from anywhere, but it is hard for them to find resources that tell them what to do. Survey your readers Now that you have built up a small audience, it is time for you to survey them. The best way to improve your blog is to get feedback from your readers. Network with bloggers The easiest way you can grow your blog traffic is to get other bloggers to link to you. But if you just hit up 100 random bloggers, you’ll be lucky if you can get a few to write about your blog. On the other hand, if you start chatting with bloggers through instant messaging and email, you’ll start building relationships with them. And when you need them to plug you on their blogs, your chances are going to be much higher. Participate in the conversation In addition to responding to the comments on your blog, you should comment on your competition’s blogs. This is a great way to get some of their visitors to come over to your website. Are you familiar with Mashable? If you aren’t, it is one of the top 100 most popular blogs on the web. One factor that led to Mashable’s success is that when they first launched, they commented on their competition’s blog. I know this can be time consuming, but you don’t have to do it with all of your competitors, just the most popular. Optimize your blog for search engines According to Alexa, Google is the most popular site on the web. So why not optimize your website for it and other search engines? SEO doesn’t have to be complicated. If you have a WordPress or Movable Type blog, this article will walk you through the steps you need to take to be search engine friendly. If you don’t have a WordPress or Movable Type blog, you can still optimize it. You just may have to put in more time. Come up with a monetization plan You shouldn’t try to monetize your blog within the first few months of blogging because it can be a big turn-off for your readers. But you still need to know how you are going to make money from your blog. Come up with a plan of monetization strategies you want to test over the next few months. And don’t just rely on the standard methods such as slapping up Google AdSense. Get creative; try out some affiliate ads and other approaches that are more integrated with your blog such as a subscription program. If you don’t want to make money from your blog, that’s fine, but in many cases, the popularity of your blog will increase as you make more money — just look at John Chow! Have someone tweet about your blog (not you or your mom) Tweeting about your blog posts isn’t enough. You need other people to tweet about your blog. Now that you have been leveraging Twitter for a while, here are a few ways you can get others to tweet about you blog: Ask your followers to retweet your message (assuming you just tweeted about your blog). Email friends and colleagues who use Twitter, and ask them to tweet about your blog. Join a social media ring. If you join a group filled with social media users, you can ask each other for tweets. Keep on feeding the fire Through services like Google Blog Search and Technorati, you will be able to find out when someone mentions you on their blog. Keeping track of this on a daily basis will allow you to thank every blogger that mentions you on their blog. By showing your appreciation, you will build up a larger fan base. Plus, those bloggers will be more likely to blog about you again because you said “thanks” to them. Don’t expect the world Most importantly, don’t expect your blog to be popular. It can take months, if not years, before your blog becomes really popular. You just have to be persistent with it. If you stop, you’ll lose the traction you built over the last month.

Do this for all of your images- this is a must.Keyword research- Make sure you are using the correct platforms to do your keyword research and that you are using the relevant keywords at least 2–3 times and not more than 4 times throughout the relevant blog post/page.Be Persistent- Perhaps one of the most important things to consider in SEO is that it is not a one time thing. You should constantly be updating your site with new content, and optimizing as much as you can (text wrapping, alt text, keyword integration,etc.)That should be more than enough to help you get started. Good luck!

Step By Step Walkthrough: How I Earned My First Dollar (And More) Blogging  Photo by NeONBRAND on Unsplash I've always been a writer. Ever since I was a kid I was either creating and drawing comic books or writing creative short stories in my first grade class. In college, the fellas I shared my dorm floor with and I would workshop skits that we'd perform — of course I'd take more the role of "writer" than "actor." Until recently have I started to explore the world of blogging formulating an income through it. I remember over a year ago I bought my first domain name- HUSTLE | LOS ANGELES | WHERES THE FIDELITY (I just typed in the address in my search bar… #cringe) I had thoughts in my head and believed I needed to write about them and share them with the world. I didn't have any strategy or plan. I just chose to write. I told myself I was going to write everyday no matter what. I wrote about so many different things. I wrote about the sex escapades I was having with a former coworker.I wrote about how I thought a "good" conversation was similar to the exchange of information similar to what a computer goes through processing 1’s and 0’s.I even wrote a review about a Normandy Cidre that I bought and drank.Again, it was pretty much an adjunct, shotgun approach to putting my voice into the airwaves. Originally, I thought the way I was going to make money doing this was to put out all the thoughts that was in my head into the World Wide Web and produce such unique and creative stories that advertisers would be lining up to take my bidding of putting their product on my site. Oh boy… While you could generate an income off advertising on your site, you are probably going to be making pennies on the dollar for a long time (if anything at all) unless you are building or have a titan of a site already that generates millions of views on a monthly basis. But then why would you be reading this article? You probably aren't there yet. You are most likely a writer or a blogger that knows their way around their own site. Perhaps you promote your material on various social media platforms. Perhaps you publish your work on information exchange/publishing sites such as Medium and Quora. And perhaps you have generated millions of views to your name. Good on you. But you still haven't seen a single dollar from all the painstaking slapping of the keyboard. Hell, you're going to need to make money to pay for the carpal-tunnel care you're going to need in the near future if all this typing persists. Over the past year I have spent countless hours and hundreds of dollars on building my platform in order to spread my word, full of its insightful value, and ultimately turn an income from all the hard work. I have finally started to do just that. Below I have a step by step guide of how I did this. I fully believe that if you adopt the practices I have laid out, you too can find a viable financial reward for yourself.  Step 1: Purchase your domain and hosting service. This is crucial.  https://bit.ly/2rwcnrl I know there are a lot of "blogging gurus" out there today that say hosting your own site is a thing of the past. They are probably saying all you need is a service to provide you with a landing page and from there, the sky's the limit. I disagree for a few reasons… The landing page provider/CRM/Email marketing service is generally more expensive than purchasing a domain and hosting service on an annual basis. Take for instance Clickfunnels- probably the top dog of landing page providers in terms of their own sales revenue and also the promises they claim to convert more leads and sales. Their entry level subscription is priced out at $97/month. You're looking at almost $1200 annually for this service and you are just starting out. Not sustainable in my opinion. I use Squarespace and have my domain and hosting at just under $250 for the year. This, for me, is a more cost effective and sustainable option for bloggers starting out.With the sites that provide a landing/squeeze page, you aren't in ownership of the address- the provider is. I own my domain. I pay for it and carved it out of the the internet. If I were to go with another provider, again let's use Clickfunnels, they are in full ownership of the domain they provide you. Perhaps in the short term if you are looking to grow a list over the course of 6 months and have the proper backing to use their software in order to do so, vaya con dios. However, if you're like me and you are bootstrapping and looking to build something great over the long haul, this isn't sustainable.When you purchase your domain (sometimes can just be your full name) you are carving out your first piece at your stake of the treasure chest of the blogging market that's ripe for the taking. Step 2: Blog everyday — write compelling articles and master headlines. The truth of the matter is, no one knows about you if you don't give them an opportunity to know about you. You have to get your voice out into the ocean of online content writing. The Overnight Success is just a myth. Perhaps there are a few people that can achieve insane virality in just a few articles, however they are on the fringe of the bell curve here. What your main focus should be in blogging is to flood the airwaves with your content. Don't be obnoxious, that can have adverse effects, but make sure you're writing consistently. Rome wasn't built in a day It's cliche, I know, but it's true. It's especially true with your blogging. So you're writing consistently and still no one is noticing your work- even on Medium or Quora… What do your headlines look like? Seriously, you need to consider this. I know you're a writer or an artist. You want to be creative and cunning with your headlines so the other creatives will recognize your brilliance. Okay, do that. Be a poor writer for the rest of your life. The real writer is also and entrepreneur and marketer. What content does your audience want? Furthermore, how are you going to convince them that your article is worthwhile? The answer is by writing compelling headlines. People do judge a book by its cover, or judge an article by its headline in this case. Jon Morrow, world class blogger, has great resources on his website of where to start with crafting optimal headlines:  https://smartblogger.com/how-to-write-a-blog-post/ Step 3: Build your Call to Action and Squeeze Page You've been gaining a bunch of traffic and getting views. You've been consistently writing and publishing valuable content for your audience. Your popularity and influence has been growing. What do you do now to leverage all of that influence. The Holy Grail of blogging is your email list. You email list is the Traffic You Own (according to Russell Brunson of Clickfunnels — see, I'm done picking on Clickfunnels). When you have an email list, you are able to direct this audience towards your content (and later your products or services) when and how you want. In order to build your email list effectively you are going to need a provider. Again, in light of bootstrapping the best provider I have found starting out is Mailchimp. They are the best because of their free plan starting out. You have the ability to grow your list for free for your first 2000 email subscribers. This is important for you aren't going to grow your list to 10k overnight (Morrow's golden number for a proper list).  (screenshot of my most recent email blast: 36% open rate ) Mailchimp allows you to grow your list and also provide landing page templates (if you aren't going the route of purchasing your own domain). You can also use plugins to add to any page of your Squarespace site. Linking your Mailchimp to Squarespace is incredibly simple. When you have built an email list, you are done just hoping that your audience will organically see your content. You now have the power to guide them straight to it. Let me define the two terms above for you briefly: Call To Action: What message you are conveying in order to get your audience to take a certain action. This is a pull to get your audience to do something. Here, it is to get or receive your FREE giveaway (ebook, guide, quiz, survey, report etc).Squeeze Page: Once you get your audience to take a specific action (click the link to the promised free product) they are sent to a landing page. Here there is only two choices for the person to take: they either exchange their email for the free product or they exit the page. It's binary. No other choice. https://bit.ly/2FVAvsR (You can find an example from my squeeze page here) Once you are able to convince a reader to exchange their email with your valuable content, you have the ability to enroll them into your sphere and take on the responsibility of crafting your future communication with them. Step 3.5: Regular communication Regular communication is key. Just because you have the email doesn't mean that you have "won" the relationship with your audience. Far from it. You have to nurture this prize you have been given with the email. The reader you gained was interested in your story. So take them on your ride. What are you working on?What are you thinking of?Where are you going?What are you building?What I have found is a once a week newsletter that is promoting valuable information that I have found, the sharing of new articles that I have written. I also like to start conversations with my audience — what are they interested in right now? What content would be valuable for them in the future? Here, you are continually building trust and value for your newly obtained fan. This brings us to the next step. Step 4: Selling your product or service This is where it all comes together and all the hard work you put in prior to this step is rewarded. You are selling your product or service that is consistent to what you've been blogging about and helps your audience solve a problem they have been dealing with. For me, my first product is my 8 Step Guide of how I went viral with over 2 million views in just a matter of a few months. There are many problems I solve for my audience in my product: How to reach millions of viewers organically without spending a single dollarHow to leverage your new found visibility into a secure credibility as a writer/blogger/influencerHow to craft an intriguing headline every reader will want to click.How to structure and format ‘The Perfect Post’How to use language to your advantage in your writing to trigger an emotional response from the reader (which encourages them to share it with someone else).The 1 habit every single content writer needs to master in order to become successful.How to transform your mindset into creating quality work that primed for viral sharing.How to identify and utilize my unfair advantage in find the right “pools” and areas to post your content thus giving you maximum exposure most people don’t know about.How to use utilize online publications and ditch your blog in order to create a massive audience & become a thought leader.Now again, I do all of my sales through my Squarespace site. You probably can open up an ecommerce store through Clickfunnels or another provider as such. Squarespace has great plugins that allow for commerce (I use the Stripe plugin — you can also use Paypal for business).  (Remembering my first sale — Got to love the process)  This is a chance for you to consider what you are going to sell. There are so many different industries within the blogging sphere that are ripe with an audience looking to solve a problem. I am working now with my boxing trainer on creating his blog and thus his future income stream. To give you an idea, we are work shopping giving away a free guide that is filled with intense ab workouts that can give you six pack abs without needing to commit to much time at all during workouts. He's a training wizard. For the first time in my life, I have a six pack. I know this is possible. This is going to be on our CTA and Squeeze page with his articles. We are then going to build a comprehensive 30 day video series — one work out a day, 4 days a week with 3 rest days that will help his audience get into the best shape of their life. This is going to be his product. Again, there are so many opportunities here. There are probably hundreds, if not thousands of people in the exercise blogging arena. One might think there isn't any more room for us. That's the wrong mindset to have. There is abundance on the internet and people are looking for answers. You are that answer. It will take time. It will take sacrifice. There will be moments you feel you aren't making any progress. There will be moments where you feel like you want to give up. You are your own bottleneck. Just as there are hundreds if not thousands of people that purchase a domain and start blogging, there are just as many who bow out of the game. Don't be one of those people and you propel your chances of winning and creating the life you always knew you could have.  https://i.gifer.com/7cXx.gif Good luck! Make More Money from Your Blog with These 5 Persuasive Writing Tips There are several differences between writing copy and writing content. Content is made to provide information. When you write copy, you are attempting to get your readers to take action in some way. You should have a lot of valuable content on your blog. After all, people come to your blog to solve problems and answer questions. There is definitely a place for writing copy on your blog also. You are eventually going to want to make money from your blogging efforts. Some bloggers make upwards of $10,000 per month and are able to quit their dreary, frustrating 9 to 5 jobs because they become very good at writing copy that is persuasive. When you know how to write so that your readers take whatever action you desire, whether that is joining your email list or buying your products and services, you can turn an informational blog into a passive income stream any time you sit down at your keyboard. The following 5 writing tips make your content more readable, while simultaneously improving the odds that your readers will follow your call to action. 1 – Always Include a Call to Action Even if you are just writing a blog post to tell someone how to find sources for bargain fashion wear, you should include some type of call to action that tells your readers exactly what you want them to do. In this example, you may be running a fashion blog. After you write the post that tells your readers how to save money when buying fashionable clothing, offer a free report or checklist that is related to the subject matter of your post in return for them joining your email list. Always add a call to action to every piece of content you write. 2 – Break the Rules of Grammar It's okay to begin a sentence with "and" or "but," even though your English teacher told you that was a no-no. Don't go out of your way to break these and other grammar rules, but when it makes sense, don't be afraid to do so. When you write like people talk, which often means grammatically incorrect, you develop a real connection with your audience. 3 – Write in the Second Person Write as if you are talking to someone personally. This means imagine you are speaking to someone in a one-on-one conversation. Writing in the second person means addressing your audience members with terms like "you," "yours," and "yourself." When you address an individual rather than a group, your readers benefit. 4 – Use the Active Voice, Not Passive The active voice is persuasive. The passive voice is not. Don't say, "The hamburger was eaten by the man." That is unnecessarily indirect. Instead, you would say, "The man ate the hamburger." Think subject + verb + object and not the other way around. 5 – Make It Easy to Read Your Content Write short sentences. Use short words. Speak simply. Don't use a big word when a small word is all you need. Add descriptive subheadings throughout your post. Make sure your paragraphs are no longer than 3 to 5 sentences long. Break up big blocks of text with white space. These practices make your content easy to scan and easy to read, which means you improve the odds that your entire blog post is consumed. There are many methods to make money from blogging. Various options are as below.: (Few of them might have already been mentioned earlier) 1) Join an Advertisement Network: The easiest way to make money from your website is to join an advertising network and then show their ads on your blog. Choosing an ad network might be a tricky task. There are many ad networks available in the market based on CPM, CPC, In-text advertising, etc. Analyze and try different ad networks to see which turn out best for you. CPM – You are paid according to the number of times the advertiser’s banner is displayed on your site. The amount you earn is typically calculated based on the number of thousand impressions of the banner (impressions = number of times the banner is displayed), often abbreviated CPM (cost per thousand, with the M being the Latin numeral for thousand). That is, $10 CPM means that you get paid $10 for 1,000 displays of the banner. Note: If you want to join CPM ad network, I would suggest trying Adversal. Also Read: Adversal CPM Ad Network Reviews CPC – Under CPC scheme, you are only paid when visitors click the advertiser’s banner on your site. The amount paid is usually higher than the pay per impression scheme. A high traffic site will probably enjoy a higher click rate than a lower traffic site although you will probably get better results if your banners are carefully selected to suit the target audience of your site. You can show ad banners above the fold, between posts to get maximum CTR. Note: If you want to join CPC ad network, try Google Adsense, Chitika, BidVertiser etc. You might be interested in reading the following articles: Chitika Ads Reviews – Earning & Payout MethodsBidvertiser Reviews – Earning & Payout MethodsEdit 1 - Chitika has been discontinued. In-Text Advertising – In-text adverting networks like Infolinks will place sponsored links inside your text. These links come with a double underline or dashed underline to differentiate them from normal links, and once the user rolls the mouse over the link the advertising will pop. Should the user click on it the site owner will make some money. Also Read: Infolinks Ads Reviews – Why Should You Go For It? 2) Join an Affiliate Program Affiliate Marketing is another efficient way to make money. This is a proven way of monetizing a blog and almost all bloggers start out this way. All you need to do is join an Affiliate program like ShareASale or vCommission and market their products and services on your site. This works on CPL and CPS basis. CPL is Cost Per Lead (Lead can be anything whether any visitor watches promoted videos, signs up to the merchant, complete one survey etc). CPS is Cost Per Sale (Whenever your visitor makes a purchase you will receive a commission). Though it is difficult to get conversion but once you promote any sale you get high commission. You might be interested in following articles as well- Why Should You Start Affiliate MarketingHow to Earn Money with ShareASale Affiliate Program?How To Do CPA Marketing?Cuelinks ReviewvCommission Reviews – Should I try this?10 Highest Paying Two-Tier Affiliate ProgramsBest Paying Affiliate Programs in ShareASale3) Email Marketing There are some bloggers who make money through email marketing. They do not advertise or sell any advertise products on their blog. They build an email list by collecting the email address of their visitors and readers and enable them to come up with a solid list of prospective buyers for whichever product you are promoting. You can build and manage list using MailChimp or Aweber. Once you have a large list you can send promotional emails to your email list and make money. But never bombard your readers with lots of emails. Send 1-2 weekly mail with offers you need to provide them with a link to a product or service you are selling. Note: You can use OptinMonster to collect emails from your visitors to turn them into subscribers. 4) Selling ad spaces on your website You can also sell ad spaces from your website in order to make money. You can always find advertisers under your website niche who are willing to promote their product on your website and in return pay you. You can either reach out to the other advertisers directly or you can make use of networking sites like BuySellAds and connect with the potential marketers. You can create a separate page where you can mention about advertising space that you can provide along with charges that you want in return. E.g. Start with an Introduction about you and your website what is it all about. Also, mention your website stats such as monthly visits and page views and provide sufficient information to advertisers. Then, at last, you can mention about ad spaces that are available on your website such as – 728*90 — Header – $$$ 468*60 — Below Post Title – $$$ 300*250 – Sidebar – $$$ 5) Selling your own products You can always join an affiliate program and sell merchants’ products and services. But it will be good if you start selling your own products. It is more profitable and can help you to make money. If your website is about SEO or WordPress or Affiliate Marketing then you can create a “How To” e-book and sell it online through your website. Similarly, if your website is about cooking, create a cooking e-book. You can also sell physical products from your website. You just need to configure PayPal or any payment gateway to charge the fee for your products and services. 6) RSS Feed Ads Website owners have started to find ways to monetize new content distribution channel such as RSS technology. FeedBurner already has its own publisher network, and you can sign-up to start money by displaying CPM based advertising on your feed footer. Bidvertiser recently introduced an RSS feed ad option as well, with a PPC scheme. 7) Offering services to your readers: Some of the services which most bloggers can offer to make money include – article writing, SEO services, blog designing, WordPress installation and much more. If you have creative writing skills then you can start making e-books for other people at high rates. 8) Related posts Selling related posts is a relatively new way of earning money. Instead of inter-linking your own related blog posts, you can link to paid posts. You can use a plugin such as Shareaholic which combines your own related posts with paid ones. Popular related post advertising companies are Disqus, Outbrain, Taboola etc. 9) Start a Membership Program: A membership program implies a paid forum where special contents are made available only for the members. You can set reasonable charges to let your visitors join as members to your forum and then provide additional facilities and services to them in return. 10) Paid Surveys and Polls There are many companies that will help you to make money to run a small survey or poll on your website. You can sign up with them, and select the kind of polls that you want to run your site. Most of these services operate under a CPM model. An example of such service is Vizu Answers. 11) Writing Paid Reviews: There are many companies who would readily send you free products for a review. You can write a review on their product or service and in return, those companies would pay you a decent sum to get their free product reviewed. You can also write sponsored posts on your website. It is somewhat similar to writing paid reviews but instead of writing a review, you need to use the name of their product in your post. 12) Creating a conference around the website If your website takes off and becomes an authority on its niche, you could create a conference around it. Depending on the size of your audience, the event could attract thousands of people, and you could make money directly from conference passes and sponsors. 13) Donations It may look weird but placing a “Donate” link or button on a website can be an efficient way to earn money, especially if your blog is a niche where readers learn and gain value from your content. There are many plugins available that enables you to insert a customized message at the bottom of each article, asking the readers to chip in for a beer or coffee. 14) Education programs Education is one of the biggest industries in the world. People are willing to pay for someone or something that will teach them and give them knowledge. You can create an educational program related to the niche of your website. It will be a very profitable job and can earn you handsome income. 15) Sell Your Website If you have tried all the possible ways to make money from your website but are not able to get success with it, you can sell your website. You can use Flippa, We Buy Websites, FEinternational etc to bid and sell your website. Keep in mind that they most used parameters to determine the value of a website is the monthly revenue that it generates, multiplied by a certain number. So, the main problem with selling your site is deciding when to do it. If you sell it too soon, you might be earning less. If you sell it too late, you may receive less money than you like. The ideal situation is to sell when your website’s income stabilizes for a few months. Source: Top 15 Ways To Make Money From Your Website

I strongly recommend that all new bloggers sign up as soon as you register for the Amazon affiliate program as well as Google Adsense. To keep it really simple and basic, there are a few ways you can earn money through blogging.   Affiliates - These are companies including Amazon that pay you to promote their website and or their products. You may get paid per purchase, per click or per coupon print depending on the offer. Some of these groups do have a minimum payout amount so you might need to earn $50 or a $100 with their organization before you get your first payment.  Advertising - You can run ads on your site either from ad networks like Google Adsense, include ads for affiliate offers or even charge for advertising space that you might sell on your own (like to local businesses. Some of these ads might pay per view and others will be per click and the organization may also have a minimum amount you have to earn to get paid.   Sponsored articles or posts - These are posts you write about a client, topic or product in exchange for an agreed upon amount. The amount that you can charge will depend on your niche, traffic and your social media following.    Paid social media - If you've been able to develop your social media following, you may be able to monetize by advertising to them. Many bloggers and marketers earn regular incomes through paid tweets, Facebook posts, Instagram posts or by hosting Twitter parties.    Most bloggers do a combination of all of the above, and depending on your audience and your niche you'll probably do some more than others at different points in your blogging. If your new, you may need to start out with ads and affiliate offers and work your way from there.

It’s definitely possible to do it, which is an important first step. Knowing exactly how you want to make money is going to go hand in hand with what sort of blog you’re looking at creating. Before you jump in, do a lot of research and have a plan. There is a great deal of literature out there on the subject, even whole blogs that make money by publishing articles instructing would-be bloggers on how to follow suit. There are a lot of schools of thought on this subject, but I’ll break down three big ones. Affiliate MarketingThis model involves dealing with vendors either directly or indirectly. Amazon is by far and away one of the most common clients Affiliate sites will use, because it’s incredibly easy. A Blog will have, for example, a list of items, an article or a single link that will point readers to specific items that the Blogger has chosen beforehand. Every purchase made through these links will yield the Blogger a small portion of the profits. It is also possible to create your own independent Affiliate store by purchasing products up-front and effectively running your own inventory. This can be a little involved and requires an upfront investment, hence the popularity of convenient arrangements as with Amazon. Private agreements can also be reached with smaller boutique clients. A method related to this is selling reviews, and many affiliate sites will use a product reviews to introduce links, whether they are for hotels, shoes or cooking supplies.Ad-BasedMany Blogs will have banner or sidebar ads. Bloggers employ these in the hopes that visitors to the site will click the ads. Every ad click is worth money. The rate is largely dependent on the site’s traffic, the quality of the ads and a number of other factors. Facebook is a great example of using targeted ads to generate revenue, and while the ads on many sites are not using as sophisticated an algorithm, the principle remains the same. Even renting space for ads can yield a degree of profit, however, much of this is again determined by site traffic and overall engagement. A blog with low engagement will see pennies per click whereas a major publication running, for example, liquor ads, is likely receiving a significantly larger fee based on rental of space.FreelancingThis method is a less direct than the previous two, and requires a different skill set. There are a great deal of outlets that pay writers, from content mills to major publications. A blog focused on Freelancing is using the blog itself as a springboard to obtain these contracts, which can evolve into full-time positions or simply lucrative one-time contracts. The blog seeks to establish the writer as a trusted expert, while the blogger makes efforts to network and create exposure while querying publications. The site then effectively becomes a portfolio unto itself, opening up opportunities to the Blogger as readership and engagement climbs. This in turn yields larger and larger contracts, but also opens the door to consulting on the fields of expertise.Generating profit from a Blog is certainly a difficult pursuit, but it can be done in as little as a few months, given the proper niche and quality content. The key is, again, to do your research and pick a topic you’re passionate for. Targeted content is both easier to manage and enables you to cultivate authority on a given subject. The market is incredibly saturated with those that see it as a quick buck, and competition is fierce, but it Blogging is most definitely something you can make money from.

My blog actually just wrote a post on this. I think this could help a lot.  Creating a blog has become one of the most popular tasks in 2020 (especially in quarantine) and it’s now easier than it ever was before. If you’re thinking about entering the world of blogging, I’m sure you’re confused and have a lot of questions. Starting a blog can seem like a daunting task; it requires thorough research and it can be difficult to know where to begin. No need to fear– here’s a simple guide on how to create the blog you’ve dreamt of creating. Getting Started Decide What You Want to Blog About To create your blog, you need to figure out what type of content you want to publish. You may have this figured out already, but don’t worry if you don’t. Start by thinking about what interests you most and imagine ways to write about that. Many sites will recommend finding a “niche” interest area for your blog to be about, but that’s not required and your blog doesn’t have to be super niche. Take our blog for example. We’re an entrepreneurship blog, yet we cover topics such as marketing, business, and lifestyle. The most important aspect to keep in mind is that your blog is your own– use your voice to make it unique. Pick a Blogging Platform To create content, you need somewhere to post your work. There are a plethora of platforms to choose from, yet WordPress is one of the top platforms bloggers are using today. WordPress is easy to use, super user-friendly and has many free plug-ins that will help your blog obtain traffic. WordPress can seem a bit confusing at first, yet check out their tutorial or this beginners’ guide on YouTube by Tyler Moore.  Find a Domain Name This part can be a little tricky because you’ll need to find a unique domain name that still speaks to your blog’s brand. Domain names are usually short, not super wordy, and are something that audiences will remember. Click here for some domain name inspiration. Remember, this name is your brand and it defines who you are. Use a Web Hosting Account Web hosting allows your blog to be visible on the internet, which is required if you’re looking to obtain page traffic. The hosting companies will literally “host” your blog on the internet, and users will then be able to access your content. The most popular hosting site at the moment that is compatible with WordPress is BlueHost. BlueHost has a monthly cost that varies between the type of package, yet the small investment will be worth it if it means your blog is noticeable. Other hosting platforms include DreamHost and HostGator, which Ryan Robinson outlines in his guide to starting a blog. Design Your Blog The way your blog looks is perhaps the most crucial step to effectively creating your blog. We say not to judge a book by its cover, but let’s be real, we all do. It doesn’t matter if you have the best-written content on your blog, because if it doesn’t look appealing, then no one will read it. You need to engage your audience as soon as they visit your page with enticing graphics and a pleasing color scheme. WordPress has a bunch of free themes to choose from, yet if you’re looking for something more unique, try shopping at Etsy for some reasonably priced themes.  Start Writing Blog Posts Your blog wouldn’t be a blog if you didn’t have any content! Once you get all the basics set up, start writing immediately. You can go back and edit the design, alter your domain name, or work on your blog’s social media marketing strategy later. For now, just start uploading some content. Keep in mind that your articles don’t have to be masterpieces; write about topics that interest you and use your own, conversational voice to get your creative juices flowing. Realize it’s an Investment Creating a blog takes a great deal of time and dedication. It’s an investment in your lifestyle and your finances. For your blog to be successful, you will need to put some amount of money into it, whether it be signing up for a host or picking a custom theme. You’ll also need to dedicate some time to working on your blog and improving it as you go along. However, this investment will be so worth it once you see it pay off in the end. Earning Money  Many people opt to start blogs because they know of the financial benefits it can provide. A lot of people will say that you shouldn’t be in it for the money, but it’s okay if earning a profit is one of your goals. Just be sure that you’re not only in it for the money, but also personal fulfillment purposes. I came across this young blogging entrepreneur, By Sophia Lee, who began her blog about a year ago. This past May she was able to make over $43,000 in that month just from her blog. Unbelievable, right? But if she can do it, so can you. Here are some ways you can earn money fast through your blog: Use advertisements Advertisements are a big source of revenue for many bloggers. You can either sell ad placements to companies or use programs such as Google AdSense or MediaVine. If you’re just starting, try using Google Ad Sense and once you gain more traffic you can start looking into other options. Utilize Pinterest You may think social media is the game changer to increasing your blog traffic, and while that is true, it’s not the social media you’re thinking. Facebook and Instagram are helpful in some ways, yet growth on these platforms is slow. Pinterest is on the rise in the world of blogging because it generates large amounts of traffic in a more efficient manner compared to other social media. Sophia Lee made a YouTube video outlining her path to a successful blog and one of the most important things she emphasized was using Pinterest to gain traffic to your page. This was the only social media she used and today her Pinterest page has over 10 million monthly viewers. All the traffic brought to her page through Pinterest made her more attractive to advertisers and affiliate marketers. Follow this guide on how to use Pinterest to gain traffic to your blog.  Embrace SEO Search engine optimization is a tool you can use to increase the visibility of your blog, thus gaining more traffic. WordPress offers the plug-in Yoast which helps you make sure your blog post is SEO-certified; it essentially assists you in making your blog more attractive. To learn how to use SEO, check out our article, or click here for our free SEO book. Write for Your Audience Let’s be real: your blog is not about you. As harsh as it may sound, your audience doesn’t care about you or your experiences; they only care about themselves. People read blogs to improve themselves and apply the lessons you’ve learned to their lives. Therefore, you need to create content about your audience. Keeping the audience in mind is such a critical aspect of blogging, business, public relations, marketing, etc. You need to write something that will appeal to them, and once you start to frame your content that way, more and more people will engage with your blog. For instance, don’t title your article “How I started my Blog,” but rather title it “How You Can Start Your Blog.” Create Courses for Purchase You may want to consider creating and selling educational courses related to your blog once you gain enough traffic. Maybe you want to create an in-depth guide on how to use influencer marketing or how to turn your start-up idea into a business. Whatever it may be, audiences who come across your blog are looking to get something of value, and if you can provide that, they’ll be willing to pay.  How to Create a Blog: Stick to It Starting a blog can be challenging, frustrating, and you may not achieve success right away. It may just feel easier to give up, but don’t do it. You’ve put in all this effort already, so why throw that all away? When you feel like giving up, push through that feeling, and keep going. Commit to making your blog the best it can be. Set aside time each day to work on your blog, even if it’s just for an hour or two. Set deadlines for yourself and create a blogging calendar to make sure you update your blog frequently. When all else fails, keep trying. KEY TAKEAWAYS Starting a blog can seem like a difficult task, but the above tips can help you get your blog idea off the ground and running. If you’re wondering how to create a blog, nothing is holding you back from doing it, so go for it. Yes, it can be a frustrating and time-consuming process, but remember why you started it in the first place. If you get what you want in the end, whether it’s monetary or personal gain, it’ll be 100 percent worth it. Keep in mind that this is your image, business, and your brand. Stay true to you and be genuine when you upload content to be attractive to an audience. Know that you can create a fantastic blog and that you are more than capable of achieving success.

Blogging is definitely a long-term “game” when it comes to making money out of it. It’s not wise to expect any income for the first few months. You may earn a few hundred if your blog is geared towards making money from the first day. If you’re really serious about it and you’re passionate about a certain topic, you can start blogging. It’s easier to grow your blog with one niche than to write about virtually anything. That said, you can always have a multi-niche blog like mine as long as the topics are not too far off. I recommend WordPress as your blogging platform. I’ve tried Blogger and GoDaddy’s website builder in the past but it’s definitely not recommended. Don’t be confused between WordPress[dot]com and WordPress[dot]org. The former is a free platform that is hosted on WordPress’ own server. It’s severely limited and no professional blogger will use it to grow their blog. The latter is also using WordPress but you have to find your own hosting. In both cases, you’re still using WordPress as a CMS (meaning that you’re using it as a website/blog builder). However, hosting of the blog is separate. If you’re under WordPress[dot]com’s hosting, they basically own your blog and put restrictions into plugins and what you can do with it. If you have your own hosting, you can do whatever you want with your blog but it’s a learning curve. I wrote a guide on setting up a self-hosted WordPress blog (a.k.a. WordPress[dot]org) here.

Make Money With Affiliate Marketing  Affiliate marketing is when you recommend a product or service to your audience using special tracking links, and then get a referral commission for every time someone buys after clicking your link. A real-life example of affiliate marketing would be when you help a friend open a bank account at your bank branch. Usually, they give you a gift card or a bonus of some sort. Similar to that many products and services online have affiliate programs that you can join. There are affiliate programs available for every industry (niche). If you’re interested in getting started with affiliate marketing, you can start by thinking about the products you already use that your readers may be interested in as well. Then you can see if they have an affiliate program that you can sign up for. You can find a huge list of products to promote from: AmazonCommission JunctionShareASaleOnce you have selected the products to promote, then you can use a WordPress plugin like PrettyLinks to manage your affiliate links. It allows you to quickly insert links into posts, create branded links, auto-replace keywords into links, and even see how each link is performing on your site. Affiliate marketing is the easiest way to make money because you can promote a wide-variety of products. Just about every popular store like Walmart, BestBuy, Amazon, and others have an affiliate program. To learn more, see our beginner’s guide to affiliate marketing and also check out these affiliate marketing tools and plugins which will help you increase your earnings. 2. Display Google AdSense on WordPress  Google Adsense is an easy way to make money from your blog. All you need to do is add a script from Google to your website and start displaying ads. You will get paid for every time a user clicks on the ad. These are called CPC ads. What is CPC? CPC stands for “cost per click.” By displaying CPC ads with Google Adsense, you receive a set fee every time a visitor clicks on an ad. The cost per click is set by the advertiser. (This is in contrast to CPM ads, where you’re paid for ad views instead of clicks. CPM means “cost per thousand impressions,” where M is the roman numeral for 1,000.) Google Adsense is a good way to start earning money online when you are first starting out. You can see our guide on how to monetize a WordPress blog with Google AdSense to get started, and this tutorial on how to optimize your AdSense revenue for more tips. Looking for a Google AdSense alternative? Try Media.net. They also have a large pool of advertisers, and their payouts are good. 3. Use a WordPress Advertising Plugin to Sell Ads Directly  Google AdSense is easy to set up, but the amount of money you can earn is limited. Each ad click earning will vary. Directly selling banner ad space on your website can be more lucrative. Instead of having to rely on an intermediary who takes a cut of the money, you negotiate the price and terms on your own. Above we mentioned the difference between CPC and CPM ads, where you are paid per click or per thousand views. While you could use one of those models for selling banner ads, most bloggers charge a flat rate instead. Charging a flat rate is easier than keeping track of views or clicks. Still, directly selling ads takes more work to manage than using Google AdSense. Instead of just adding a bit of code to your website, you’ll have to negotiate the pricing, come up with an agreement and terms, and take care of administrative work like invoicing. However, using a WordPress ad management plugin can make the process easier. We recommend using AdSanity, it allows you to manage Google AdSense as well as your own ads. To learn more, see our guide on how to sell ads on your WordPress blog. 4. Sell Sponsored Blog Posts Some bloggers aren’t interested in displaying ads to their audience and wonder how to monetize a blog without ads. With ad networks, you lose some control over the content displayed on your site. Some readers will get annoyed or offended by ads, and more and more people are using ad blockers which affects your earning potential. An alternative way to monetize a blog is through sponsorships. A sponsorship works just like it does in sports, TV shows, or other industries. Basically, a company pays you to represent their product, talk about it, and promote it to your readers. To get started, it’s a good idea to put together a one-page media kit that details your traffic stats, social media following, audience demographics, and any other data that will make your site more appealing to advertisers. Then, you can approach companies to negotiate a sponsorship deal. When publishing sponsored posts, it’s crucial to know about the laws in your area about disclosure. For example, in the United States, a blogger who publishes a sponsored post must comply with the FTC’s Endorsement Guides. This includes disclosing whenever a post is sponsored. You can do that by adding a sponsored post prefix to your post title in WordPress. 5. Get Paid to Write Reviews  Similar to sponsored posts, you can also make money by writing paid reviews on your site. This is a slightly different monetization method than a review site with affiliate links, as mentioned above. Instead, you get to try out products related to your niche for free, and even get paid for writing a review. The process for doing this can be similar to getting sponsored posts. You’ll want to review products that are relevant to your niche, that your audience would be interested in. You can approach companies on your own to ask about doing paid reviews. There are also websites like PayPerPost that can help to connect you with businesses who may be interested. 6. Earn Money Online by Flipping Websites  If you know how to build a WordPress website, then you’re way ahead of most people. Sometimes entrepreneurs like to buy already established websites that they can use for their own businesses. If you can build a WordPress blog and start getting traffic to it, then you can sell it and make money for your efforts. This requires knowing the type of websites in demand, and how to price and sell them. There are websites like Flippa that serve as auction sites and brokers for selling websites. 7. Get Public Speaking Gigs as an Influencer  If you are promoting your own brand along with your blog, then over time you will get a decent following establishing you as an influencer in your space. You can utilize this recognition to get some public speaking jobs. Many bloggers make a lot of money by speaking at conferences. Speaking at events whether you are paid or not helps you promote your blog and your personal brand. If you are good at networking and public speaking, then you would be able to find lots of new opportunities on the way. Here are some general tips you need to keep in mind if you want to make money as a paid public speaker. Be an expert in your field. A popular method is by having your audience pay to access certain content or areas of your site. Here are a couple of ways to do that. 8. Create Restricted Members Only Content Your most loyal readers are huge fans and may be willing to pay to read more of your work. You can create a members-only area for them to share more in-depth blog posts, downloads, videos, audio content, and more. Membership sites can be a big time investment since you must continually create premium content for your paying members.
