I suggest starting with “StartUp” (first option on the left). Click “Get Started”.Next, register your domain OR choose that you already have a domain. This is where you’ll put in your “http://www.yourblgonamehere.com”. The thing that I LOVE about Siteground is you can create a new domain RIGHT from the program. Click “Proceed”.SaveEnter in your contact and payment information. I suggest getting the privacy and site monitoring services. This is to ensure your privacy. But of course, they are optional.Install WordPress. You can also have Siteground set it up for you!CHOOSE A THEME The theme of you blog gives it the look and feel that you want and allows you to structure your blog how you see fit. Unless you’re a coder I suggest having a theme. There are two parts to a theme: the framework (think of this as the frame of a house) and the child theme (think of this as the paint and landscaping). The framework makes up the bones or foundation of your blog. I use and suggest Genesis. This is what I use for myself and the reason being is it’s the best choice and works with many of my favorite child themes. As for your child theme this is what you can think of as the blog design. There are many options out there. I recommend Restored 316 and the options on Creative Market. A brand I’m really loving lately for well priced (think under $50) designs is Code + Coconut. Simple and pretty themes that also work with Genesis. It will take some time to choose this but know you can always change it. If you feel particularly stumped with any of the above you can always ask for help. I use a company to help manage my blog and install my designs called WP Help. You might notice that some blogs have things like opt in boxes, social share buttons, and more. These are plugins they install on their blog (many are free) to customize the look and feel of the blog even more. CHOOSING A LOGO If you’re looking for a logo you can design it yourself with tools like Canva or Photohop. If, like me, you’re not great at designing there are a few tools that you can use to really help you out. I love the designs inside of Creative Market. You simply search for a logo you like and can even find designers who can customize it. I wanted a bit more detail to my logo but when I looked to hire a designer I felt it was crazy expensive. Then I discovered 99 Designs. Y’all, this is a game changer! If you need anything designed (even a website) I highly recommend this. Here’s how it works: specify what you’re looking for. Then, you’ll hear back from dozens of professional designers and be able to narrow down your favorites and what you like on your website. Then you’ll pick your top 3 designers and they battle it out to create the best graphic for you. You pay one price. It’s much cheaper than hiring someone and you get literally dozens of options. I am obsessed! STEP FOUR: HIT PUBLISH One of the most common questions I’m asked: When should I start publishing on my blog? My answer? Yesterday. There is no right time. The sea will not part, you will not receive some magical sign. Many people are afraid to share. It can be scary to reveal more of yourself online. That’s what a blog is, isn’t it? But in order to succeed you just need to go for it. Yes, I do suggest to have an “about me” page, a “contact” page and maybe a page dedicated to what you are interested in or intend to write about, but it’s not necessary when you first hit publish. Just putting yourself out there is enough. As you start writing you will learn what works for you and this will help you structure your other pages and your blog itself. Remember, your blog can change. My blog has had a number of major changes over the years: name change, about a dozen different blog designs, writing, direction, etc. I find that as you grow and as you write your blog will grow with you. The important step as you go is finding your ideal reader. Who do you want to read your blog. You MUST map this out. And it’s important to think about this every step of the way. You cannot improve your blog, make money blogging, or drive traffic without having a solid understanding of your ideal follower. For me, my blog is a mix of things but my reader is clear: she is a 20-40 something woman who wants to live a meaningful life through experiences and goals. Tailoring your work to a specific audience is one of the best things you can do for your blog. When you try to write to everyone you wind up writing to no one. So sit down and figure out who your ideal reader really is and that’s when you will find your community. Writing great content is not only how you’re found online, it’s establishing trust from readers. When you create confidence in your audience they are more likely to stick around, share your blog, and also buy from you. STEP FIVE: DRIVE TRAFFIC TO YOUR BLOG How do you drive traffic to your blog? There are only two things you need to really drive traffic and create a money making blog: killer content and a community. I’m going to dive deep on what that means for each. First and foremost, write great content. It sounds simple but it isn’t. In order to build a raving audience that continues to come back again and again you need to write wonderful content. You need to write something of value. This can mean vastly different things to different people. Maybe you’ll discuss your struggles with infertility. Many women out there can connect with the same feelings of hopelessness. Or you’ll write something funny about going to the grocery store in a foreign country. People will connect with this or it will make them laugh. If you’re a social media expert you’ll tell how to grow your Facebook page in a simple way. All of these provide value and offer inspiration. I like to call this “foundational content.” You want to write content that makes people say: wow, I want to read that blog again. And then they do. They subscribe to your newsletter or they follow you on social media. Now, you’ve started forming a community. This community is the one that will keep coming back again and again. But more than that they will share your content and will most likely BUY from you! Think about a blog you love. Why do you follow it? Now apply that to yourself. You need to create and foster a community and build it up with consistent, great content. That doesn’t mean you need to post daily. I post about 2 times a week and feel happy with that (and receive about 150,000 views a month on my blog). You need to do what works for you. Truthfully, you can’t have one without the other. If you have a community you won’t want to piss them off with less than sub-par content. If you have great content that will encourage your community to spread the word and keep coming back for more. Creating both is how you get on the path to continually driving traffic and making money. Now of course, social media plays a vital role in this community and driving traffic. For this I suggest being on all platforms but concentrating efforts on one or two where you see the most potential. For example, I see the most traffic (personally) from Pinterest and Instagram. Therefore, I focus most of my effort on those two social media platforms. I regularly share to Instagram and Pinterest and I am constantly learning how to improve my skills on both. STEP SIX: CREATE AN OPT IN Okay, you’re writing great stuff and building your community. You’re starting to gain traffic. But wait, how can you keep them around?! Better yet, how can you make money? You need to create an opt-in. This free opt in will ensure that they stick around and hopefully buy from you in the future. When you create a newsletter or email list for your blog it gives you a chance to select the exact type of people that you want to keep coming back again and again. For example, let’s say you write a post on your delicious healthy recipes. You create an opt in for a free meal calendar. Eventually, you will sell your recipe eBook. Since you created the freebie, you already have people on your email list who are your target market and would be very interested in purchasing from you. Take it from me, when I first started my email list I was at 0. Within 5 months I hit 5,000 newsletter subscribers and was making about $1,500 a month – just from my email list! Your newsletter is your direct connection to your audience. Creating an email list is how you turn casual readers into buyers and lifelong fans of your blog. Many people are worried about how often they should send out a newsletter (aka, they don’t have time) or that they aren’t sure what to send out to people. There is no rule book when it comes to creating an opt in. You don’t have to send something out every time you post, every week, or even every month. I personally only send out my newsletter when I want to share something important (like a big life change), something valuable (like a deal or a sale on a product I’m using I think they might like to use), or when I’m promoting my own products or hosting a webinar. Honestly, I might share to my newsletter every three months or so. Here’s a detailed guide on how to create a newsletter for your blog. I recommend using Convertkitbecause it’s a straightforward, easy-to-set-up platform, created by bloggers for bloggers. I have used MailChimp in the past (it’s free for up to 2,000 subscribers) but Convertkit is just so much more intuitive and helps me to make more money becuase I can easily segment my list. I also think it’s easier to create the freebie and link it up to my blog through Convertkit. Here’s the process: 1. Write a post on a topic you’re passionate about. 2. Create a “freebie” that people can opt in to that’s related to the post. Example: an ebook, checklist, or pdf guide. You can create this straight from your computer. 3. When they “subscribe” automatically send them an email with their freebie. I do this seamlessly in Convertkit by creating a form that automatically sends them the download. 4. That’s it’s!! Only email your list when you feel like it. When you create an email list don’t worry about having multiple welcome emails or opt ins. Start simple and you’ll learn as you go. The important step is just to start it and you’ll see over time which posts work when creating an opt in. STEP SEVEN: MAKE MONEY BLOGGING Let’s get something clear, in case you just skipped on down to this step, you can’t make money blogging without the above. You need to know who you’re blogging to, why, create great content, and a community. That needs to be present before you can make money. They are all related to each other and reflect back on whether or not you start to monetize your blog. To me, there are many ways to make money blogging. But in reality, there are 4 key ways to create income for a blogger. Those are: advertising, affiliate marketing, sponsored opportunities, products (digital and physical), and online education. I want to take a brief look at each and how you can use them for your blog. ADVERTISING The ads on the sidebar, top, middle, and bottom of a blog are advertising. These can be from places like a network such as Google Adsense. Here’s how ad networks work: you get paid per view and per click on the ads. Now, don’t get me wrong, it’s not anything like $1 per click and 20 cents per view. It’s much lower than that. But it still adds up. The key here: the more views, the more money you’ll make. Back in the day, in the advent of blogs, bloggers could make a full time income just from ads. Not the case anymore. Unless you’re getting millions of hits a month, you’ll need other strategies to make a full time income. How to succeed with advertising on your blog: the more page views, the more likely you’ll grow your advertising income. AFFILIATE MARKETING One of my favorite ways to monetize a blog is with affiliate marketing. Here’s how it works: you share about products, services, anything you love already on your blog. With affiliate links you link to the product and make a small commission on it when your readers click and buy. I love to share the products that help me grow my blog. And I make sure to only share about products that work for me. For example, I’m a huge fan of Hootsuite, a scheduling tool for social media. When I blog about it (for example, this post on How to Schedule Blog Posts Like a Boss) I know if others click and buy, I make a small commission. It’s already something I’m using and loving and my readers can trust that I will only share about products I recommend. I also suggest creating posts that relate to the product or how you use it. When you show your audience why it matters or how to use it they are more likely to buy it. Again, this echos back to creating a community and sharing valuable content. How to succeed with affiliate marketing on your blog: only share products and services you love. Write posts that directly relate to the product and take it a step further by sending out an email to your list to encourage them to buy the product. SPONSORED OPPORTUNITIES Sponsored posts are ones where payment comes from either a company or third party that pays you a flat fee to include their product, service, event, location, you name it in your post. For example, I worked with Visit Britain earlier this year to write about my experiences in Manchester and Liverpool. I was paid a fee to write about my honest opinion. I’ve also worked with companies like Pollinate Media and Collective Bias that help you connect with companies looking to work with influencers. If you’re wanting to see how to work with companies check out how to make money with sponsored posts. OR, if you’re a travel blogger, check out the full guide on landing sponsored travel. No matter what stage you’re in you can get sponsored blog posts or social media shares. How to succeed with sponsored opportunities on your blog: only take things that your readers would love. Write the post in your normal blogging voice and deliver on time. Don’t be afraid to negotiate and reach out to others. PRODUCTS OR SERVICES As far as products go, you can sell anything! From an eBook, course, coffee mug, t shirt, one-on-one coaching, you name it. Most of the time these products do take some leg work meaning, you have to set them up, create the payment system, deliver the product or online education, and promote them. But along with this, there are more opportunities for you to monetize. Instead of getting a portion of the profit you get all the profit. If you can provide value, whether a service or product, you can sell something from your blog. The key is to understand what your audience needs and how you’re uniquely qualified to deliver it to them. For example, let’s say you’re a graphic designer. You often write about how to design simple graphics. You start a course on how to design your blog from scratch. You can sell the course through Teachable (or really any platform that lets you sell courses or books) and promote the course on your blog, newsletter, and social media. A place I recommend to sell your Digital Products or courses is SamCart. This is what I use to take payments for my eBook, Lightroom Presets, and my online course. It’s easy to use and makes selling your stuff simple. You can check out my shop here. If you’re selling a physical product a great place to do this is Etsy, or you can have your own store front with Shopify. How to succeed with products or services on your blog: have a clear understanding of who you’re selling to and WHY they need this. Make a plan of action and stick to it! No matter what area you choose to focus on, it’s a good idea to have more than one iron in the fire. I personally bring in income from all of the above ways and it ensures that no matter what, I have one income stream coming in. Even if you’re a beginning blogger you can still make an income, especially when you have a solid understanding of your reader, a newsletter in place, and some social media. Don’t forget to analyze your results along the way. That goes for your whole blog. Keep track of your stats so you can see where to improve and what topics people gravitate towards. STEP EIGHT: LEARN A SKILL I wholeheartedly believe the best way to grow is to keep learning. I am always taking an online course, reading a book or blog, or listening to a podcast to learn what will work for me online. Enhancing your skill set not only helps you improve it also helps you make money. Remember how I said above about concentrating some efforts on social media? Learning a new skill and improving your social media, SEO, writing development, keyword research, etc. is a great way to continue to grow. I have taken classes on webinars, email marketing, SEO, business, Facebook ads, and so much more. Do your research to make sure the offer or course or book is legitimate. Then go for it. Make sure to hold yourself accountable along the way. If you got down to the bottom of this post… congrats! I know this was a doozy. But I wanted to completely cover the best way to monetize your blog, no matter where you are in the process. The best way to create a profitable blog is when you are passionate about what you do and share valuable content with your readers.

Creating a blog that makes money puts one thing as its number one asset at all times: the audience. You’re providing content that is designed to be consumed and read by anyone and everyone. It won’t appeal to anyone and everyone, but it’s not designed to, otherwise you’re trying too hard to please too many people and end up pleasing no one at all. Blogging is more than just writing about something you’re interested in. It’s about growing and retaining traffic. Here’s how you go about that. Choose a niche. A niche is a specific population who have a shared interest or hobby in the same thing. Usually people pick a niche that they’re invested in as well and it’s an easy step. Do you enjoy collecting monopoly boards from around the world? Chances are that there are plenty of other people who enjoy that as well. Find out if people will care about this niche and potential topics you’ll write about by doing some keyword research. Google’s Keyword Planner is a commonly used tool, or you can try a third-party tool like The Hoth. Plug in a few keywords based on the topics you’ve brainstormed, like “collecting monopoly boards”. It’ll reveal how many people are searching for these terms each month (the more the better).Figure out who your ideal reader is: In the marketing world, we call this exercise creating your “avatar”. It’s an imaginary person who would read your content based on their demographics and behaviors. Maybe your avatar consumes content on certain podcasts or follows specific social media accounts. Once you’ve figured out where your avatar hangs out, it makes it easier to create content they would enjoy reading.Research keywords: If you haven’t come across this term, it’s pretty much synonymous with blogging. Mastering the art of Search Engine Optimization (SEO) gives you a huge boost up so that your content is found on the first page of Google’s search results. Start by identifying niche-driven keywords. Keywords are basically what people type into Google when they’re looking for something. The more specific you can get your keyword, the more likely it is that your content will resonate with a reader. Try to include this keyword in your headlines and the body of content but don’t force it, as Google can tell when you’re stuffing it in there for the sake of it when it contextually doesn’t make sense. If keywords and SEO is new to you, not to worry. Focus on creating quality content that leaves your reader feeling like you’ve given them something of incomparable value.That’s a pretty standard formula on how to generate traffic. It usually takes at least 6 months before your content will start ranking on Google’s search engine. But once it does and you are gaining a big crowd of traffic, you can think about monetizing your site. There are a number of ways to earn passive income from your content. Affiliate marketing: To earn money with affiliate marketing, you’d recommend a service or product to your readers. A cookie gets stored to track whether or not they go on to make a purchase. If they do buy something, you earn a commission on the sale. In the example of the motorbike site, you might include affiliate links for clutches in a “best of” guide parts that wear out quickly. A lot of people use Amazon Associates but you can consider Commission Junction or ShareASale if the products you describe a very niche. If you have a lot of traffic, you can earn some serious money by applying for private affiliate programs that pay much more than the popular ones. Just remember to keep your products relevant to the affiliate links you’re including.Advertising: You’ll probably be aware of all the ads that pop up when you browse a site you love visiting. Sometimes you might click on one. You can have these ads pop up on your site as well by applying for display ad networks. Google Adsense is the most common one that bloggers use. You’re usually charged on a cost per click (CPC) basis, where you get paid a flat rate each time someone clicks on an ad. Other display ad networks might use the cost per thousand impressions (CPM) approach, where you’re paid for every thousand times your ad was shown. CPM is a useful approach if you’re getting a lot of traffic since it doesn’t need someone to click on it. However, this just raises awareness of a product or service. Advertisers often want people their ads to result in people visiting their page, which means a click is more desirable. Compare the rates to see which ones work better for you.Online courses: If you can establish yourself as a real authority in your niche, people will want to learn from you. Hone in on that demand by creating a course or series of courses to address your followers’ desire to be better at a skill in your niche. They sell more than other products you can feature on your site which factors in the amount of work it takes to produce a polished course. You can also have a tiered pricing system so people can access gated content according to their membership level. Taking motorbikes for example, you might teach people how to thoroughly clean a motorbike in a basic course for $100. At the premium membership level for $500, you’ll teach customers how to maintain it and which parts you have to change, in addition to best practices on cleaning.Ebooks: Reading is still considered one of the best ways to learn. And creating an ebook is a time-efficient way to do so. When you generate a lot of content, you can distill all of it into one curated ebook that focuses on one specific topic, which adding in an additional chapter or updating certain chapters. While readers could technically discover this themselves, what you’re doing is providing a convenient way to learn more about one specific topic in the niche in a highly focused method. Every chapter in your ebook is about that idea and you won’t be bothered with random noise. This is great if people are looking to fast track learn about one area in a short space of time.Paid webinars: Webinars are a largely under-utilized form of marketing and a way to provide educational content. Similar to a course, you’re providing knowledge in a condensed session which gives customers a chance to interact and ask questions if anything crops up.Diversifying your revenue across many streams of income means you’ll be earning a lot through your blog, maybe even more than your regular job. You might find that the work required to meet the demands of content creation is beyond what you can handle as a one-man operation and you need to hire a team. As you continue to match your blog’s growth, you’ll scale your blog into a valuable online asset. If the time comes when you get tired of it or want to pursue a different project altogether, you can sell the blog. These types of online businesses sold for an average of $99,525.01 on our marketplace in 2019. What would you do with that amount of capital?

There are several ways, actually, provided you can actually write. Alternatively, you can try freelancer sites like Upworks, Guru, Fivrr etc. They often list job offerings for content writers. One word of warning, though: They payment on these sites is usually very low and there are also some bad sheep out there. Finally you can try and start your own blog. Provide good content on a very regular basis, build a fan base and monetize through ads and/or merchandise from books to t-shirts. If you are into blogging and would like to monetize it through “web development” as your niche. Then you should do the followings:- 1: Finding Ideas from Keywords You have likely heard the term "keyword research". This is the act of finding keyword phrases that are relevant to your niche and deciding whether or not it is appropriate to build content around that particular keyword. This is going to be the “root” of all your search engine optimization success, so we are going to be tackling keywords here before we get into creating content. A keyword is simply a word or phrase that people search for in the search engines. Every time you do a google search you are entering a "keyword" into the search box. Ultimately, the goal of your keyword research is to find keywords that you can get rankings in Google, Yahoo, and Bing with, all while attracting a relevant audience. You will be using the keywords that you find in this lesson to build content around. This will lead you to search engine rankings and traffic to your website! Each page you create will be targeting a keyword... 100 pages targeted 100 keywords = 100 potential Google rankings. This can and will lead to mass amounts of traffic and those that follow along with this training are going to see their traffic continue to go up with every "keyword targeted" page or post that they create on their website. Remember, Google and other search engines are around because of CONTENT and if you can deliver quality content (that targets low competition keywords), you will be able to get great rankings! The simplest way to do it is through Alphabet Soup Technique - Using Google Instant to Find Keywords. Well, it’s a simple technique that you can use with a little help from Google. Actually, we’ll be using the Google Instant feature that occurs automatically when searching for anything using the Google Search Bar. Have you every noticed that when you place a subject or question in Google search, that Google automatically populates your search menu with similar or related searches that you’re looking for? For example, I type in “lose body fat” into the Google’s search bar. Google Instant will automatically populate my search with the top search results that are similar to my keyword or keyword phrase. The way the Alphabet Soup Technique works is by.. 1.) Take your blog post topic or keywords that you would like to investigate, and put it into the Google search bar. 2.) Then add the letters of the alphabet, one at a time, and see what is actively being searched for on Google. You can also add a letter and go through the alphabet at the beginning of your keywords to see what Google Instant comes up with. Or you can use a question at the beginning of your keyword phrase starting with.. WhoHowWhatWhenor WhereThen you will see a whole new series of keyword phrases that you can potentially use as keywords for your next post on your website. 2: Create Quality Content Content is going to be the "meat" of your site. Content will be the difference between getting lots of traffic becoming an authoritative site, and you not seeing much in the way of results. Plain and simple, content leads to rankings in search engines and rankings are going to lead to your website traffic and revenue! Google, BING, & Yahoo LOVE Content! These are the top 3 search engines and make up over 98% of searches online. Want to know how you can leverage these search engines and get mad traffic to your site? The answer is: Quality content. The most important aspect of any content, whether it is text or video is that it is created with the reader in mind. Real people are reading this content so you want to deliver something that is relevant and interesting. When writing content you want to keep in mind that you are writing it for people, not just for Search Engines :) Being original, candid, and building your personal brand is the best way to succeed within any niche, so please make sure you do put some effort into creating your own content. There is nothing wrong with getting some concepts or ideas from elsewhere to incorporate in your page as this will save you time. Refrain however, from copying and pasting other people's work as you will lose ANY chance of ranking if you have duplicate content on your site. People are going to be navigating on our website, they are going to be reading our content, and they are going to be buying from us based on our recommendations. They are going to be engaging in discussions, they are going to be sharing our content on social networks, and they are going to be trusting us and our brand. Don’t lose sight of this, I see it all the time where people get so lost in the process of what they are doing that they dehumanize their website to the point where no visitor would get any value. It is all about the EXPERIENCE you create. 3: Find Affiliate Programs to Promote Google – the easiest way to identify relevant affiliate programs, simply insert your keywords into the search engine and you may find products that suit your niche.AdSense Ads – many of the AdSense ads appearing beside Google search results, someone's blog, and even on your own blog are likely to be products with affiliate programs attached. It is sometimes worth checking out the ads (don't click the ads on your own blogs, you will be penalized) to find out the potential affiliate partners. Very often, you will be surprised to find some great affiliate programs that you might not know.Affiliate networks – there are quite a few affiliate networks around that list many affiliate programs. Most of these have search functions to allow you to type in keywords and find promotions relevant to your niche. Check out MarketLeverage, Clickbank, and Commission Junction.Alex Founder of ManagingYourFinance.Com

Making money from a blog is definitely doable, it just takes time and dedication. If you want to make more than pennies, I strongly suggest you focus on creating quality content and building a loyal community first. Here’s the harsh truth - starting a blog solely for the purpose of monetizing it can leave you sorely disappointed. More than that, it’s easy to get discouraged if your initial efforts don’t pay off. BUT. As long as you’re passionate about the content you’re putting out there, other people will be as well. Your blog will grow organically and money will soon follow. Pretty straightforward, right? That being said, let’s say you’re at the point where you’d like to start experimenting with monetization. If that’s the case, you can try one or more of the following strategies.  Advertisements This is the most common and simple way bloggers earn cash – by leveraging Google AdSense to incorporate banners or other types of advertisements on their websites. This means that Google does much of the heavy lifting for you and you don’t need to be in direct contact with advertisers. Needless to say, it can be a plus when you’re just starting out and are nervous about reaching out to brands yourself. If AdSense doesn’t work for you, there are other similar platforms available, like Media.net | One of the largest ad-tech companies worldwide or Infolinks. Sponsorships On the same note, there are influencer networks (IZEA, Mention, Influenster, Webfluential etc.) that can help you discover great sponsorship opportunities. This makes them a great starting point for bloggers looking to build relationships with brands. Brands often want to pay you a set amount for a sponsored post, in which you talk about their product or service. As expected, prices and requirements vary depending on brand. You also need to have a decent following to be able to score sponsorship opportunities. Sometimes, brands will offer to send you a product in exchange for a review, with no money changing hands. This is pretty common when you’re not an established voice. As your blog grows, you’ll be able to better negotiate a fee as well. Affiliate links Another common way to generate income from your blog is through affiliate marketing. Here’s how this works: a brand has a product that it wants to sell. They give you a unique link to incorporate on your blog. Once that’s done, every time a buyer comes from your site you earn a commission. Bloggers can either get affiliate links directly from brands if they have a partnership or join programs like Amazon Associates. A lot of big brands have affiliate programs. You just need to check out their website to see exactly how they work. Selling products Once you have a solid community around your blog, you may be able to earn good money by selling digital or physical merchandise directly to your followers. Merchandise can entail anything from e-books to online courses to apparel, depending on what your niche is. You can even sell memberships to your blog, offering paying clients access to extra content. That’s what Mark Manson does, for example. Building credibility This one is the least straightforward of the bunch, but it can also be the most lucrative. You can use your blog to build a solid personal brand, which will lead to more opportunities. Again, these opportunities will largely depend on your niche. For instance, you may score a new job if you’re diligent about showcasing your skills through blogging. Or start consulting for other companies. If you’re a writer, you may end up with new freelance gigs. Speaking engagements are also not out of the question. All these endeavors will bring in extra cash as a direct result of your blogging efforts, which is pretty cool. To sum up A smart way to go is to experiment and mix and match as many ways to generate income as you feel are suitable for your blog. How to Make Money Blogging Today, I'll break down the four main ways people blog money. Everyone is described in detail and I hope it will help you to understand how bloggers make money from their websites. Who knows, it could encourage you to start your own blog!  Advertising One of the first ways most people try to make money blogging is by advertising. Some types of advertisement bloggers use to make money, including pay per click ads, direct advertising and sponsored posts. Pay-Per-Click ads pay-per-click advertising is usually offered by advertising networks that are large companies that contract their products with brands and retailers. Instead they turn around and sell back the advertisements to website owners and bloggers. The pay-per-click is typically very small, but some networks provide more than others. Google Adsense and Media.net | One of the largest ad-tech companies worldwide (related to Yahoo!) are well-known ad networks. Furthermore, there are also some networks not connected to these internet giants. In my blog in the sidebar and below and above the text of my blogs, I have pay per-click ads. Whenever one of my readers clicks on these advertisements, I receive a small amount of payment. The explanation for the ad works is that Google and Yahoo use cookies and web history data to target ads to things you probably want. The advertisements I see when I visit forums, for example, usually contain Kate Spade, Maurices or Amazon items that I recently watched. Such companies know which websites you visit and use these data directly to tailor the ads to you. Pay-per-click ads are typically one of the best ways to make money blogging when your blog starts. That's because, irrespective of traffic, Google Adsense and Media.net | One of the largest ad-tech companies worldwide support only any website (so long as you don't have banned materials, such as porn or something). Most beginners make money blogging from day one with this sort of publicity. But the drawback is that your blog can look embarrassed and just earn money while harming the ad user's experience. Specific ads and sponsored posts You should start looking for direct advertising after your blog has been around a while and a reasonable amount of traffic. Many businesses can even reach you through your contact page. Such corporations and brands pay for placing a "banner ad" on your website or for promoting an article on your blog. FTC guidelines say that you must report if a blog post is funded and reputable companies are in agreement. Yet bloggers are also asked all the time to host supported contents without any "spammy" client reports. Such companies only want to get a connection from your website. You really don't know if someone sees your content or clicks your connection. Instead, they use Google's rating only to boost their own. This is contradictory to the recommendations of Google and the FTC. If you're caught doing this, your website could be disciplined inside Google's ranking system. This will drive you down the search engine results list and have a negative effect on your amount of traffic from search engines. Bloggers may expect to be provided throughout the board for direct advertising, but for a limited period of time, usually one year, this is done at a flat rate. Spam companies are going to try and get bloggers to publish their contents and send them a $10-20 connect. You can up to $200 for one link if you have a high-ranking blog. Legitimate businesses are willing to pay more, and may give you several hundred or even several thousand dollars for traffic on your blog, particularly if you are promoting them on social media, emailing your list, or endorsing multiple posts on your web. Affiliate Marketing Another way to blog money is through affiliate marketing. Affiliate marketing is when a blogger is paying to buy something by using a connection to their website. Instead of pay-per-click ads where the blogger is only paying for your ad click, you usually have to buy something for the blogger to receive payment. You have to join affiliate programs to make money from affiliate marketing. Many organizations have their own individual programs for which you have to apply. Nevertheless, there are also affiliate networks, such as Commission Junction, Share-a-Sale or Amazon Associates, where many companies and products can be found on your blog. After you have entered an affiliate program, a special connection with a special tracking code is issued. It can be used in a blog post, in social media or online shop. If anyone uses your connection to buy something, a portion of the profit is paid to you. How much can you do with affiliate marketing? Depending on the company with which you operate and what the reader is purchasing, the amount will vary significantly. On every single sale, bloggers will earn a few cents or a few hundred dollars. Different companies will offer their clients different percentages. To order to increase the volume of affiliate sales, bloggers typically write a review of a product or a guide to several products. Those allow readers to buy something because they already have faith in you. Reviews can also draw search engine traffic for individuals who are looking for a product they already think about buying. Some bloggers know they must be cautious with the ads of sponsors so that they don't harm their followers. Most bloggers are therefore only going to promote stuff if they have experienced them. Affiliate marketing advantages There are a variety of really good things about affiliate marketing. Next, you can write a single blog post, create a website and share it for years on social media and keep making money from it. Your tracking code usually works for a couple of days. If a reader clicks on an Amazon link on your blog post, anything they buy in Amazon for the next few days, will be credited to your website as a sale, even if it is not your particular product.

Bloggers use a number of different techniques to monetize their websites. Here are a few examples;  1). Advertisement Bloggers place advertisements on their blogs. Although revenue per click is very low, if your blog generates a substantial amount of traffic it can be very profitable. However, with too many ads you risk annoying your users. 2). Affiliate Marketing This is where you refer the user to a product from a third party, such as Amazon. If the user purchases the recommended product you receive a small percentage of the revenue. This is in my opinion one of the most profitable techniques, especially if you can recommend high price items. 3). Offering a Service If users are getting value from your work then why not charge additional services out. Many bloggers turn into paid consultants on their niche. If you have a solid loyal user base then why not offer additional content for a cut. There is no clear winner in terms of monetization strategy, what method works best is unique to the blog. Often blogs will implement multiple monetization strategies and that can be valuable. What is important is you do not spam your users with monetization, build a user base based on quality information and then slowly implement monetization. You will earn nothing without respecting your audience. Hope that helps. I am happy to answer any additional questions you may have.

To become a blogger, you need to learn how to write engaging, informative content for your readers. When writing a blog post, you need an outline, something like this: Blog Post Outline Message—What you want to communicate to your readers.Title—The title of your blog post. It should grab attention and reflect what your post is about. Thd job of the title is to get the reader to read the first sentence.Opening sentence—The opening sentence also has to get the reader’s attention. The job of the opening sentence is to get the reader to read the next sentence.Closing Sentence—This is the last sentence of your post. It should leaver your reader with satisfying closure. I like to re-iterate my blog post title or opening sentence here, bringing the blog post full circle. This isn’t always possible, but it’s an effective way to end a post.Opening Paragraph—Introduces the subject matter you’ll be writing about. The last sentence of this paragraph should lead the reader in to the body of the blog post.Closing Paragraph—Summarizes the topics covered in the body. This is where you write any conclusions you have with respect to the subject matter.Body—The main part of the blog post. This is where you create at least two or three topics related to the subject matter, then write about them in detail. You can have as many topics as you want in this section.You may have noticed the order of the outline looks jumbled. This is intentional. By following the order in which each part of the outline is written, you clarify what it is that you want to tell your readers. When you sit down to write the main part of the blog post, it will be much easier. You will also be pleased with the results. I use this approach on all blog posts, whether my own or for a client. Hope this helps!

In her own words, Kimra Luna’s childhood life was just “horrible”. But perhaps that’s an understatement. If you listen to her interview, you will not find suitable words to describe it. Nothing can explain what this young, beautiful girl had to go through during her childhood. Yet she endured it all and became one of the most sought after internet entrepreneurs, business strategists, bloggers, speaker and influencer.  Photo Credit: Kimra Luna | Facebook What would normally be described as a normal day, was a day littered with domestic violence and chaos. She would even be afraid of going to school because people would taunt her as weird, abnormal and gay. All types of racist remarks would be thrown at her. It was living hell both inside her home and outside. When you listen to her inspiring story, you reasoned within yourself, “how does someone still get the courage to live happily when her childhood was littered with so much violence, abuse and chaos? How can someone go through so much and still make it in life?” Well, Kimra Luna is not your ordinary girl. She was a dreamer, right from the start, and no amount of garbage thrown at her would even for a moment, make her flinch from her lifelong dream of getting out of poverty and living her dream life. Although everyone else at home was unhappy, she decided from early on, that she would be different. At age 16 she frequented the library and borrowed books that would later prove to be invaluable in her future career. One such book that greatly influenced her was “How To Win Friends and Influence People” by Dale Carnegie. She insists that her childhood was not something she would wish on anyone. She grew up in Boise, Idaho, in a family plagued with sexual abuse, physical abuse, verbal and mental abuse and a string of drunken father figures moving in and out of her life, whose abusive behaviors painted a stark picture of how cruel the world can be. She was physically abused by her own mother repeatedly, sexually molested by close family members and almost beaten to death by her eldest brother. For Kimra Luna, she had only one wish—to get the hell out of Idaho, escape from her family, escape from poverty—and run away from all those horrible people who were responsible for her hurt. That opportunity came when she had her first foray into business filling a local, albeit unique, need in her hometown, Idaho—booking punk rock bands. She checked the CD jackets of her favorite bands and started cold emailing. And sure enough, within weeks she was booking legendary punk rock bands, whom she accompanied on countrywide tours. This crazy stint somehow made her a cool $90,000 a year. That stint took her to California, where she continued doing her thing, but unfortunately, the stint didn’t last long. While working, one of her close business associates swung her a surprise and raped her. That was something she didn’t expect, and it took her by storm. Her life fell apart and from then on, she couldn’t concentrate any longer. Business went down, and, eventually, she had to close down. The year was 2008 and this was in the middle of the economic downturn. In her own words, she says that she was even thankful the economic collapse happened, because it gave her the much needed break. She decided she had had enough. Shortly after, she met and fell in love with a wonderful guy who became her husband, and the father of her three children. She found herself a married mom of two kids (they had only two kids by then). Neither spouse had a college degree or a job, so they found themselves living on welfare for the next four years with her husband's parents in Southern California. With no money, and raising two kids on welfare, life was tough, and the pressure was just too much. Finally, her husband got a good job with FedEx, which culminated into a journey across the country to Virginia. In a way, this was the only option to get off of welfare. With no friends or family, she became a stay-at-home mom living in Virginia. Inevitably, she drifted into boredom. She got so bored that she decided to search the internet about the possibility of starting a blog. Being crazy about health and wellness, she wanted to start a blog about vegan food for mommys. Using her iPhone to research and follow health and wellness blogs, she came across many blogs about food and wellness, and that kind of intrigued her. So she said, “I think I’m going to do that. I’m just going to become like a blogger.” So she decided to ask her husband to buy her an iMac from a tax refund that came back, and he said, “Okay”. So they spent all the money on an iMac, although she didn’t even know how to use a Mac computer. She had only used a PC her whole life and this was many years back, so this was like a whole new adventure for her. She decided to learn everything she could about blogging, and how to start and grow an online business. She would Google things like, ‘how to start a blog’, ‘how to start a successful online business’, and things like that… This introduced her to people like Pat Flynn, James Wedmore, Rick Mulready, and others—online entrepreneurs who greatly influenced her career and her life. She started following them from day one. So she said, “All right, I think I’m going to write about health and wellness stuff and things like that”, but she also wanted to make money. “When I first started, I had to do everything on limited time, because I had my two little ones. I also was homeschooling [the children] and my husband was working a full time job, between eight to ten hours a day.” — Kimra Luna. When the the kids went to sleep, she would work on her business. Nine to midnight was her time to educate herself to ‘grow her business’. As she tells it, “it was a constant streaming of keeping knowledge and inspiration buzzing in her ears.” She spent countless hours listening to podcasts and audio books, like Think Rich Grow Rich by Napoleon Hill or law of attraction tapes by Abraham Hicks. “When I started learning about the law of attraction and started studying… wow. Like… I can create my life! And I started going down that path.”, she states.[1] She built her online business in the evenings and weekends. She grew her blog to 100,000 unique viewers a month without paid traffic, using only Pinterest, Facebook group and YouTube. She ended up with a large following on her blog, Facebook group and YouTube, just sharing life, health and wellness. By then, she didn’t even have what you may call a business or a brand. She happened to come across a network marketing company that was selling organic health products so she thought that she could grow her network by blogging about the products and also sell the products to her Facebook audience. Her network grew quickly due to her online audience until the company started noticing. However, as the network started growing, the company was not happy with her marketing and recruitment strategy. In addition, they were not comfortable with her hair style (her hair is dyed pink colour along with nose piercings). Besides, the company had a crappy compensation plan, and the pay was poor considering the hard work she was putting into it. Eventually, she had to part ways with the company. She ended up stripping the blog off of the company’s products and replacing it with her own content. Meanwhile, she had grown her audience to a whopping 20,000 members on her Facebook group and over 2,000 email subscribers. By then, her audience were asking for coaching and teaching lessons about how to start and grow a Facebook group and how to start a successful online business. So she started building an online business around that. Leveraging her blog audience, Facebook and YouTube, she decided to launch an online course teaching people what she knew about growing a successful online business, blogging, branding and creating Facebook Ads. That business made her almost $1,000,000 in sales in her first year. She went on to build a successful business and a brand that made her an instant hit around the internet. She started doing webinars and launching training programs, and her audience continued to grow. She also started appearing on magazines and blogs like HER, HuffingtonPost and BusinessInsider. From there, her business just took a dramatic turn. She went from under $1 million to over $1.5 million a year by 2016. Now she’s doing almost $3 in sales per year. Kimra Luna is a personal branding and online business strategist. She helps freedom-seeking entrepreneurs to stand out, captivate their audiences’ attention and monetize their authentic brands online. From a standing start in May 2014, she’s grown her email list and combined social media followings to over 200,000 people. Online entrepreneurs widely regard her Facebook group, The FreedomHackers Mastermind, as one of the most supportive places on the internet. Kimra is the creator of Be True, Brand You, her signature online program which has over 1500 students currently enrolled.[2]  The writer is a blogger, writer, entrepreneur and life coach. How can one make money starting a blog How to Start a Blog: Step-by-Step Okay, if I haven't dissuaded you just yet, and you're serious about launching the next Mashable or TechCrunch or whatever other blog you might think is wildly successful in your eyes, then here's what you need to do in a step-by-step fashion. The more you prepare and plan, the more likely you'll be to succeed in the long term. 1. Pick a Topic Get clear on what you'll write about. Define a topic or niche, and design all your content around those things. This will help you to not only laser-focus your writing, but also to build digital products and services that compliment your content. This allows you to attract customers in, enticing them with your highly-informative posts, then tempting them with a lead magnet before dropping them into your sales funnel (more on that shortly). 2. Select a Platform While Wordpress is the most popular platform for blogging by far, there are others out there that can be leveraged such as a micro-blogging platform like Tumblr, Blogger.com and even Medium. Custom domain names are important if you're serious about making money from the blog you start. Rather than relying on a third-party-hosted subdomain, find a short but relevant keyword-rich (if possible) domain name that's descriptive of your intended topic, industry or niche. Use BlueHost, HostGator, 1&1 Hosting or any other number of domain name providers to source your domain. If you're at all concerned about things like SEO, when selecting your domain name, you should adhere to the following suggestions: Use a known top-level domain (TLD) such as .com or .netKeep the domain short, no more than 15 characters or soTry not to purchase a domain name with hyphens, since they're more often associated with spammersAvoid using self-hosted subdomains to rank or categorize posts4. Find a Good Web Hosting Company There are loads of good hosting companies out there. If you're starting a Wordpress, self-hosted blog, there are a near-endless amount of options. The important thing is to do your due diligence and pick the right one that's suitable to your budget and to ensure that the service-level and up-time guarantee is there. At the beginning, you'll likely want to start out with either a Managed Wordpress solution or a Virtual Private Server (VPS), and scale from there. Eventually, you'll probably need a dedicated-hosting solution with a CDN (below) once you break through a few thousand visitors per day. 5. Caching and Content-Delivery Networks (CDNs) Use a system like W3 Total Cache or WP Super Cache and turn on browser caching to ensure that you speed up the delivery of your webpages. In the beginning, this might not seem as important. But as you grow and your traffic increases to thousands of visitors per day, this will be critical. Use Google’s page speed insights to test things before and after the installation. It's also important that you setup a CDN, which will speed up the global delivery of your content. For example, your page might load relatively quickly in the United States, but what happens when someone in Australia tries to load your content? CDNs replicate data across multiple repositories around the world, and make content delivery ultra-fast. This is important for the user's experience because most people who are foced to wait even a few seconds for a page to load, often abandon the website and go to the next one in the search results. W3 Total Cache integrates with Amazon's AWS and MaxCDN, two very good options when it comes to CDNs. 6. Enable Permalinks In Wordpress, you should enable permalinks before getting things off the ground, which will give you nice canonical URLs that are SEO-friendly. Permalinks are located within the settings > permalinks section of your Wordpress admin and select the post name option. 7. Install the AMP plugin The Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) Project is an initiative by Google to speed up mobile accessibility to a large degree of their content. The AMP specification, which you can read more about here, helps to thin down a webpage to its basic structural components with scaled-back JS and minified CSS code, makes for lightning-fast page speeds. 8. Install Google Analytics Install Google Analytics so that you can keep track of your efforts while building out your blog. This is a great way to keep track of your results while using the URL campaign builder when dropping links in social media and other places so that you can effectively determine where your traffic is coming from. 9. Setup Google's Webmaster Tools Anyone who's serious about building a blog and making money, needs to leverage Google’s webmaster tools to see what keywords they're ranking for and any messages that would impact their ability to rank. This will also allow you to submit an XML sitemap and track keyword impressions along with click-through rates. This is one of the most useful tools for growing your site or blog through constant analysis of your efforts. 10. Learn SEO the Right Way Although you shouldn't start a blog with the intention of optimizing it to oblivion, you most certainly should understand the fundamental principles of search engine optimization so that you pay attention to the key aspects that will impact your ability to rank on search engines like Google. Begin with, and digest and implement that information. Learning SEO is a long and drawn out journey. You should always be increasing your knowledge and expanding your skill set. 11. Regulary Build Useful Content If you're serious about succeeding with your blog, you need to build useful anchor content. It needs to be engaging, keyword centric, insightful, unique and well written. Don't write your content for search engines. Rather, write your content for humans while also paying homage to search engines and what they want. Simply put, it's a skill that develops over time with practice. It's also important to regularly publish your content on a weekly basis. 12. Sign Up to an Email Marketing Platform The best avenue for making money from your blog is through email marketing, plain and simple. Hands down, this offers one of the quickest and surest strategies for earning an income through your blog. But before you get there, you need to sign up to an email marketing platform like Aweber, ConvertKit, MailChimp, Constant Contact, InfusionSoft or any other number of platforms that exist out there. 13. Build a Lead Magnet If you're serious about marketing anything online, rather than opting for running ads on your blog (which won't make you real money unless you have at least hundreds of thousands of visitors per day) or engaging in affiliate marketing, you should build a topical lead magnet that will sell a digital product or offer that you create in the back-end. The lead magnet will entice people to sign up to your list and provide you with their email address. 14. Build a Digital Product and Position Your Offers Email marketing and lead magnets are all designed to help you build out an automated sales machine. However, you need a digital product, service or other kind of offer in the back-end to do that. You can create multiple offers or products, that can lead people up a value chain towards your high-ticket sales. 15. Create a Sales Funnel Take the time to build your automated sales funnel. There is so much involved with sales funnels, but the basic premise is that your visitors will show up to your site by discovering your content, drop into your sales funnel through an offer via your lead magnet or some other tripwire, and they'll then be led through a journey with drip-fed messages at some periodic schedule that will allow you to sell your products and services on autopilot. 16. Get Social Building a blog isn't easy by any measure. To help you along the road towards success, you have to get social. Not only by linking up with other like-minded bloggers interested in online marketing, but also by sharing and engaging with others on social networks like Facebook, Instagram and other social media platforms. 17. Market Your Content The single most important strategy you'll find for building up a blog and boosting your visibility on search engines like Google, and my all-time go-to strategy for rocketing up the search rankings on Google's SERPs, is content marketing. Marketing your content is an intricate process that involves long, seemingly-never-ending hours of building more useful off-site content that links to your primary anchor content, but it's well worth it. You can use this single strategy to rank number one on Google's searches for nearly any keyword if it's done the right way. There's most certainly an art to this as well as a technical outline and to doing it the right way. Don't try to spam or overstuff keywords in an effort to market your content by any means. 18. Monetize Your Content Let's face it, starting and running a blog can get costly. Don't expect to get rich overnight. However, you can take certain measures to monetize some of your content along the way. Be sure that you remain topical with your content and that your lead magnets help to drop people into a sales funnel that will eventually sell your high-ticket items. However, aside from that, you can always opt to generate small amounts of cash flow by doing other things such as creating articles that will lead people to courses or audiobooks that you've developed, or building out video tutorials that will ultimately sell some big package or system that will help to teach people whatever it is that you're really good it. There are numerous ways to monetize your content and make money from your blog, but don't try to take shortcuts along the way. Don't look for the fast-buck if you're serious about your long-term results. Take action and stay persistent if you want to succeed and achieve your. There are 3 main ways bloggers make money. Advertising. This requires a high level of visits to your site, aka web traffic. The more people visit your site, the more they see the ads, and the more you get paid. You can use an advertising network, or sell direct advertising space to other companies. You can also sell advertising in the form of sponsored posts, where companies pay you to write a blog post or email about their company and/or product.Affiliate marketingWhen bloggers sell other people’s products on their site and get paid commission on the sales, it’s called affiliate marketing. This can be any kind of product - digital, service, or physical. Commission rates vary between 25–75%. Affiliate marketing can be as simple as Amazon affiliates, to more in depth, like ongoing referral fees for a particular service you use. This also comes down to a numbers game. The more people who visit your site, the more chances someone will purchase one of your affiliate products. The bonus here is that you can also send affiliate links through email to your email list, where your buy-in rate might be higher.Product salesMany bloggers sell their own products. This could be branded “swag”, such as mugs, bags, t-shirts, or calendars, etc. Or this might be physical handcrafts, like hand-lettered posters, clothes, or other things you might find on Etsy or at a craft sale. Or you might sell digital printables, such as checklists, planning sheets, and worksheets that help solve problems. One of the more popular items to sell for bloggers is an ebook. Just about every blogger out there will eventually write an ebook for sale. This can be anywhere from 20–100 pages, depending on the experience of the blogger and the depth of the topic. Another popular item for bloggers to sell are e-courses. These are combinations of videos, text and worksheets that lead participants into solving a problem by following a step=by-step lesson plan. And many bloggers will offer services through their blog. Graphic design, coaching, and virtual assistance are the most common, but you can offer any service you can sell. Having a lot of traffic and a dedicated, growing email list is key to success with this kind of marketing.
